entries: Les riches clients demandent parfois des remèdes exotiques, et cette apothicairerie est heureuse de les leur fournir. Elle est dirigée par Teeg Drims (homme gnome). En plus de vendre des réactifs de base, il y a une chance que des potions plus rares soient en stock :

items: 1d4 {@item potion of water breathing||potions of water breathing}

entries.name: Town Hall / Guardhouse
entries: L'hôtel de ville de Queen's Haven sert à la fois de lieu d'annonces importantes et d'endroit où les riches habitants peuvent poster des ordres de travail pour les mercenaires ou les aventuriers, qu'il s'agisse d'un service de garde ou du nettoyage d'un nid de vermine indésirable.

Comme la plupart des gardes sont en service dans le quartier d'Eventide (ou gardent d'autres propriétés locales), les PJ trouveront l'hôtel de ville plutôt vide, à l'exception de quelques gardes qui seront heureux de fournir des indications en cas de besoin. Le capitaine Mersen lui-même est de garde à l'Eventide.

entries.name: Outlying Village Homes
entries: Il y a plusieurs domaines coûteux dispersés dans Queen's Haven, tous privés, et au-delà du noyau immédiat du village. Bien que cela ne fasse pas partie de l'aventure principale, les PJ peuvent vouloir visiter l'un de ces manoirs privés à plusieurs étages pour diverses raisons. Rappelez-vous simplement que ces maisons sont grandes, chères et probablement très bien gardées.

entries.name: Weakening Diafol's Influence
entries: Les joueurs doivent affronter le démon avant la fin de la représentation, mais le fait de disposer de plus de preuves leur donnera des indices sur la meilleure façon de perturber son plan et de révéler sa véritable nature.

items: Bien qu'aucun des cultistes de Diafol n'abandonne le démon de son plein gré, avec suffisamment de force excessive, les adeptes de Diafol pourraient être persuadés de trahir. Bill Horton a pris soin de ne révéler l'identité secrète de Diafol à aucun de ses adeptes.

Bill Horton est loyal à Diafol jusqu'à la mort. Si Bill n'a pas été révélé comme faisant partie du complot démoniaque, il défendra Diafol si le démon est découvert (utilisez le bloc de stat {@creature cult fanatic} des livres de règles de base pour représenter ses capacités).

Un dispositif magique rudimentaire mais puissant. Lorsqu'il est détruit, le pupille libère une explosion d'énergie psychique dans un rayon de 3 mètres. Toute créature vivante dans la zone doit réussir un jet de sauvegarde de Sagesse {@dc 15}, ou subir 3 ({@damage 1d6}) dégâts psychiques. Une fois le quartier démoniaque détruit, la véritable identité de Diafol peut être détectée par des moyens magiques.
Le {@item emerald keystone|RolledTold12|keystone} doit d'abord être retiré à son propriétaire, Bill Horton.
Détruire l'émeraude brise partiellement l'enchantement et empêche de délivrer de nouvelles commandes à ceux qui sont sous l'effet d'un {@object emerald pendant|RolledTold12}.
Le {@item emerald keystone|RolledTold12} a 8 hp et un AC de 10.

Le simple fait d'enlever un pendentif ne suffit pas à briser l'enchantement. Les commandes faites à partir du support de la clé de voûte resteront verrouillées en place pendant 24 heures après le retrait.
Dès que le {@item emerald keystone|RolledTold12} est détruit, les effets du {@object emerald pendant|RolledTold12} se dissipent.

entries.name: Confronting Diafol
entries: Si les joueurs ne trouvent pas le moyen de découvrir l'identité de Diafol, ou s'ils ne parviennent pas à forcer le démon à se montrer, celui-ci se contentera de rester caché. Dans le cas contraire, s'il est révélé, Diafol attaquera.

Bien que déguisé en barde elfe, la véritable apparence de Diafol est bien plus sinistre. L'âme de Darlene a été consumée il y a longtemps et son corps n'est plus qu'un réceptacle pour le pouvoir du démon. Au fur et à mesure que le corps de Darlene est attaqué, la fausse forme se consume pour révéler une parodie tordue de forme mortelle, un misérable homme malade. La peau pourrie se déchire et se détache de sa forme décharnée, et une substance noire fétide s'échappe de ses blessures. Malgré son apparence, Diafol possède une force incroyable.

S'il est révélé, il se battra immédiatement, voulant préserver le contrôle qu'il a sur son public captivé. Malheureusement, sans sa voix directrice, le public enchanté commencera à échapper à l'emprise de Diafol. Lorsque {@creature Diafol, scion of enthrallment|RolledTold12|Diafol} combat le groupe (voir les blocs de statuts des PNJ), lancez une position d'initiative pour le public avec un {@dice d20} non modifié. Puis lancez 1d10 au début de chaque round :

entries.caption: Audience Actions
rows: Le public utilise tous ses mouvements pour {@action dash} frénétiquement dans une direction aléatoire. Pour déterminer la direction, lancez un {@dice d4} et attribuez une direction cardinale à chaque face du dé.
Le public ne bouge pas et ne fait rien pendant ce tour, continuant à profiter du "spectacle" comme si de rien n'était.

Le public utilise son action pour se battre entre eux dans un soudain élan de violence. La plupart seront occupés à essayer de s'attaquer les uns les autres, mais certains peuvent se balancer sauvagement sur les PC proches. Lancez {@dice 1d12} pour déterminer combien de membres potentiels du public décident d'attaquer les PC. Utilisez le profil {@creature noble} des livres de règles de base pour représenter le public. Si des gardes sont présents, utilisez le {@creature Queen's Haven guard|RolledTold12} sous le {@adventure NPC statblock section|DemonQueensHaven|3}. Les gardes attaquent les PC à la discrétion du MJ.
Les spectateurs peuvent agir et se déplacer normalement, prenant soudainement conscience de leur dilemme, mais ils ne sont pas libérés de l'enchantement et ne peuvent pas attaquer Diafol.

entries.name: If PCs Have Defeated Diafol
entries: Avec le dernier coup porté, la forme physique de Diafol commence à brûler. Le soufre emplit l'air tandis que la forme humanoïde décrépite se réduit en cendres noires. Les membres du public commencent à reprendre leurs esprits alors que l'influence démoniaque relâche son emprise. Les membres survivants des Jousting Notes interrompent soudainement leur performance. Ce n'est que lorsqu'une explication claire est fournie que les nobles présents commencent à comprendre à quel point ils ont frôlé le péril mortel. Ils demandent immédiatement que des précautions supplémentaires soient prises pour éviter que ce genre d'incident ne se reproduise.

Sofia Espada, chevalier du Frêne Blanc à la retraite, est heureuse de rendre service. Avant de prendre ses nouvelles fonctions d'inquisitrice en chef, elle s'arrange pour dédommager les courageux héros qui l'ont crue en temps de crise : 1 000 pièces d'or, son étoile d'argent et une lettre d'éloge du chevalier sage et voyageur.

entries.name: If Diafol Escapes, or is Undiscovered
entries: Sans savoir où le démon s'est échappé, il est difficile de dire quels étaient ses objectifs, sans parler des dégâts qu'il a causés. Peut-être a-t-il appris la leçon de la sous-estimation des mortels et gardera-t-il ses distances avec Queen's Haven.

Mais là encore, il n'y a aucun moyen de savoir si ce n'était pas juste une autre partie de son plan. Quoi qu'il en soit, Sofia est reconnaissante pour l'aide apportée à son enquête. Elle va rester un peu plus longtemps en ville pour aider à soigner les blessés, bien qu'il soit probable que les nobles demandent qu'elle soit à nouveau renvoyée. Cette fois pour n'avoir pas réussi à identifier correctement la menace démoniaque. Incapable de fournir de l'argent pour le dérangement, elle offre l'étoile d'argent en gage de sa gratitude.

data.name: Main Adventure
entries: {@adventure Hoist the Jolly Gobbler!|JollyGobbler}
Rien de bon ne peut venir d'une tribu de gobelins réquisitionnant un dirigeable gnomique ! C'est aux PCs de faire équipe avec les gnomes pour récupérer leur vaisseau !

data.name: Adventure Craft
entries: Comment mener une campagne pour une gamme variée de joueurs tout en donnant à chaque héros son moment de gloire.

entries.name: Class-Centric Adventures
entries: E.L. Thomas

entries.name: As a game master, you must strive to keep all of your players fully involved in every adventure.
entries: Vous vous efforcez d'y parvenir, mais ce n'est pas toujours le cas, surtout si vous avez un groupe de joueurs aux préférences d'aventure variées. Certains aiment le hack-n-slash, d'autres les énigmes, d'autres encore les mystères, et d'autres préfèrent les jeux de rôles plus lourds, etc. Vous n'arriverez pas à satisfaire tous vos joueurs tout le temps, mais vous pouvez au moins donner à chacun d'entre eux un jour au soleil et construire des aventures autour de la classe de leur personnage. Donnez à chacun de vos joueurs une session de jeu où la compétence particulière de leur personnage est requise. Ainsi, ils seront la vedette, au moins pour une soirée.

Maintenant, je ne dis certainement pas que vous devez axer chacune de vos aventures ou même de vos sessions de jeu sur l'un ou l'autre de vos joueurs, bien que vous devriez essayer d'avoir au moins un test, une rencontre ou un moment dans chaque aventure pour chacun d'eux. Je suggère de faire les aventures centrées sur les classes au moins une fois tous les trois ou quatre niveaux de personnage (disons une fois aux niveaux 1-3, puis 4-6, puis 7-9 et ainsi de suite). De cette façon, si vous avez quatre joueurs dans votre groupe de jeu habituel jouant un combattant nain, un clerc elfe, un voleur halfling, et un magicien humain, vous pouvez vous en sortir en faisant quatre aventures centrées sur la classe au total du 1er au 20ème niveau. Je vous l'explique.

Au 2ème niveau, faisons comme le clerc elfe : {@class cleric||clerics} ont accès à leur caractéristique {@classFeature Channel Divinity (1/rest)|Cleric||2||Channel Divinity} au niveau 2, alors pourquoi ne pas les laisser en avoir besoin ?

entries.name: Restless Dead
entries: On trouve des tombes vides dans le cimetière local. Pire encore, il semble que les corps qui y étaient enterrés se soient déterrés d'eux-mêmes. Maintenant, non seulement les joueurs ont une meute de {@creature zombie||zombies} qui erre dans les environs, mais ils doivent aussi découvrir qui ou quoi les a ressuscités. Vous pourriez travailler sur des tests de {@skill Religion} qui dévoilent l'iconographie d'un dieu maléfique ou d'un culte de la mort. Peut-être que le sol sur lequel se trouve le cimetière est devenu impie d'une manière ou d'une autre, et que ces zombies n'étaient que les premiers à se lever, puisqu'ils étaient les plus récemment enterrés. Le clerc doit accomplir une série de rituels compliqués pour sanctifier le terrain, ce qui lui demande de dépenser un {@classFeature Channel Divinity (1/rest)|Cleric||2||Channel Divinity} pour y parvenir. Si les rituels sont interrompus, tous les morts peuvent se lever en même temps. Ou bien, le clerc découvre que les zombies sont rassemblés autour et à l'intérieur d'un vieux mausolée et les PJ doivent chasser ou tuer la horde de zombies - qui est bien plus nombreuse qu'ils ne le pensaient - pour pouvoir accéder et détruire l'objet qui provoque la résurrection des morts. Faites comprendre que sans le clerc, la situation serait encore plus grave. Non seulement cela renforce le joueur clerc, mais cela fait comprendre aux autres combien il est précieux de l'avoir à ses côtés. De plus, une horde de zombies donne à tous les PC quelque chose à chasser et à combattre. Cela pourrait même donner au sorcier une chance d'aider le rituel et l'enquête. TOUS les PCs pourraient participer à la protection du clerc pendant qu'ils font le rituel. Nous avons donc quelque chose à gérer pour chacun des PC, tout en faisant du clerc le point central.

Au 5e niveau, vous pouvez planifier votre deuxième aventure centrée sur la classe et vous concentrer sur le halfling {@class rogue}. Au 5e niveau, votre voleur possède la plupart des caractéristiques cool, comme {@classFeature Expertise|Rogue||1}, même sans {@classFeature Evasion|Rogue||7} et les gros trucs de haut niveau comme {@classFeature Expertise|Rogue||6||secondary Expertise}, plus de caractéristiques d'archétype, et les trucs fous comme {@classFeature Blindsense|Rogue||14}, {@classFeature Slippery Mind|Rogue||15}, et ainsi de suite. Vous pouvez donc lancer un peu de défi à notre petit voleur. Je l'adapterais à son {@classFeature Roguish Archetype|Rogue||3} particulier. Supposons que notre voleur halfling a le {@class Rogue||Thief Roguish Archetype|Thief}.

entries.name: Trap-Laden Vault
entries: Votre petit voleur est contraint de pénétrer dans un labyrinthe rempli de pièges et de gardes pour récupérer un MacGuffin à nommer en son centre. Il peut s'agir du crâne d'un sorcier mort depuis longtemps, d'un trousseau de clés qui ouvre des portes planaires, d'une plante magique ou d'un fruit nécessaire pour sauver une ou plusieurs vies, ou même d'un calice incrusté de bijoux. Cela peut être n'importe quoi. Pour obtenir le McGuffin, notre voleur doit passer ou vaincre les monstrueux gardiens, déjouer ou éviter une série de pièges mortels, franchir les multiples portes verrouillées qui se dressent entre lui et le prix recherché, et essayer de ressortir. Si vous voulez rendre les choses encore plus difficiles, vous pouvez faire en sorte que le voleur accomplisse la tâche sans laisser de trace de ses actions.

Pour faire participer les autres joueurs, vous pouvez avoir besoin de la force ou des capacités de combat d'un ou plusieurs d'entre eux. Peut-être la magie, ou du moins la connaissance de ses rouages, est-elle nécessaire. Et si le coffre-fort piégé tourne vraiment mal, vous pourrez toujours utiliser les sorts de guérison d'un bon clerc. Quelle que soit la façon dont vous gérez la situation, n'oubliez pas que le voleur est la star de l'aventure.

Jusqu'à présent, vous avez réussi à donner à votre clerc et à votre voleur une chance de jouer dans une aventure. Si vous avez bien fait les choses, vous avez probablement réussi sans qu'ils le sachent. Ensuite, il y a le combattant et le magicien. Donc, un vers le 8e niveau et un vers le 11e, parce que nous voulons pouvoir faire un deuxième jeu centré sur la classe pour tous nos héros (13e, 15e, 18e, et enfin 20e niveau). Le {@class fighter} est en plein combat-mojo self, avec deux {@classFeature Martial Archetype|Fighter||3} caractéristiques, {@classFeature Extra Attack|Fighter||5} et trois {@classFeature Ability Score Improvement|Fighter||8||Ability Score Improvements} ou {@filter Feats|feats}. En gardant cela à l'esprit, nous donnons à notre combattant ce pour quoi il excelle : nous lui donnons du combat !

entries.name: Until the Gate Falls
entries: Alors que les PJ visitent un village de montagne ou un petit fortin de garde, il se trouve qu'une horde grouillante d'humanoïdes se dirige vers le village pour le massacrer et le détruire. Qu'il s'agisse de {@creature goblin||goblins}, {@creature hobgoblin||hobgoblins}, {@creature bugbear||bugbears} ou {@creature orc||orcs}, choisissez-en un ou utilisez-en un mélange avec quelques monstres de siège plus gros ({@creature ogre||ogres}, {@creature troll||trolls} ou un géant). Les habitants du village ou du fort savent que la bataille à venir est impossible à gagner s'ils restent sur place. Leur seul espoir de survie est de fuir en utilisant un tunnel de fuite ou un sentier de montagne secret. Pour que la fuite se fasse avec un minimum de pertes, la horde qui arrive doit être tenue à distance pour donner aux fuyards le temps de se mettre en sécurité. Quelqu'un doit être le rocher dans le fleuve de la mort pour retarder la horde. C'est là qu'interviennent nos héros et une minuscule force suicidaire de volontaires. Ces volontaires ont besoin d'un chef de bataille expérimenté, et il n'y en a pas de plus adapté que notre combattant nain.

Vous avez maintenant donné au combattant de votre joueur ce que tout combattant désire : une bataille glorieuse et une chance de faire une fin mémorable. (Nous n'avons pas vraiment l'intention de tuer notre nain, mais il faut qu'il en ait l'impression). Notre combattant doit tenir un mur ou une porte jusqu'à ce qu'un signal soit donné, puis s'enfuir si possible (le plus souvent dans un combat à pied) et renverser un éboulement ou effondrer un tunnel au dernier moment pour éviter que ceux qui ont réussi à s'échapper ne soient écrasés.

Tous les autres PC peuvent jouer des rôles dans un tel scénario. Le voleur peut être un éclaireur, un sniper et un soutien pour votre combattant. Le clerc peut aider à maintenir en vie la plus grande partie de la force du combattant aussi longtemps que possible, tout en prêtant sa masse à la mêlée. Le sorcier peut servir d'artillerie ou aider ceux qui fuient en utilisant la magie. Il peut aussi aider à déclencher l'éboulement ou le tunnel qui s'effondre grâce à un sort bien pratique.

Enfin, nous avons notre {@class wizard} à mettre en vedette. Basons l'aventure du magicien autour de son {@classFeature Arcane Tradition|Wizard||2} choisi (puisqu'au 11e niveau, le magicien possède toutes les caractéristiques de la tradition des arcanes, sauf la dernière). Par exemple, disons que notre sorcier vient du {@class Wizard||School of Evocation|Evocation}. Nous pouvons faire reposer son aventure sur les capacités de {@subclassFeature Sculpt Spells|Wizard||Evocation||2} et de {@subclassFeature Empowered Evocation|Wizard||Evocation||10}, afin de nous assurer que le sorcier est bien au centre de l'aventure.

entries.name: The Spell Seal Tower
entries: Au fil de leurs aventures, le sorcier découvre un astrolabe âgé qui mène à une légendaire réactivité magique d'une richesse et d'un savoir inestimables : la tour du sceau magique. On dit que la tour se déplace à travers les nombreux plans d'existence, apparaissant une fois tous les vingt ans sur un même plan. Bien qu'il soit facile de trouver la prochaine apparition de la tour à l'aide de l'astrolabe, il n'est pas possible de pénétrer dans cette construction magique. Il y a sept sceaux qui nécessitent le lancement de sorts pour être déverrouillés. Si tout lanceur de sorts a une chance d'ouvrir un sceau, seul un évocateur peut le faire en toute sécurité. La raison en est que de nombreux sceaux nécessitent des sorts à zone d'effet et que d'autres créatures vivantes doivent se trouver dans la zone d'effet, parfois même le lanceur de sorts. C'est là que {@subclassFeature Sculpt Spells|Wizard||Evocation||2} entre en jeu. Il n'est pas facile de convaincre trois de vos amis de rester à toucher un orbe juste à l'endroit où une boule de feu va être lancée, à moins que vous puissiez assurer leur sécurité. En plus des sceaux de sorts de sculpture, il existe des sceaux de dégâts qui nécessitent qu'une certaine quantité de dégâts de sorts soit infligée en une seule attaque pour être débloqués. Pouvoir ajouter votre modificateur d'Intelligence à un jet de dégâts grâce à la capacité {@subclassFeature Empowered Evocation|Wizard||Evocation||10} donne certainement un avantage à votre sorcier et peut faire la différence entre lancer un seul {@spell lightning bolt} ou plusieurs pour obtenir les dégâts nécessaires pour briser le sceau.

Sept épreuves de sorts mélangées à une poignée de combats de monstres gardiens basés sur la magie, et vous obtenez une aventure sérieusement centrée sur les sorciers. Remplissez la tour de butin de sorcier avec des potions, des parchemins, des baguettes et des bâtons, et l'aventure sera encore plus axée sur les sorciers. Ajoutez-y sept objets puissants (disons qu'ils sont tous rares ou très rares et qu'ils ont été utilisés pour alimenter les sceaux) et les compagnons de votre sorcier ne demanderont qu'à vous accompagner pour avoir une chance d'obtenir un tel butin. Il n'est pas très difficile de convaincre votre barbare préféré d'aider un sorcier s'il a une chance de mettre la main sur un {@item Belt of Fire Giant Strength} ! Si cela ne fait pas de votre sorcier le centre d'attention, rien ne le fera.

Bien que les aventures centrées sur les classes demandent un peu de travail de votre part, voyez si cela n'incite pas vos joueurs à s'intéresser davantage à votre jeu. Votre seul problème sera alors qu'ils en voudront encore plus.

entries.name: E.L. Thomas
entries: est un concepteur de jeux, un auteur et un joueur enragé qui rampe dans des donjons de papier millimétré depuis près de quarante ans et qui n'a aucune envie de s'arrêter. Il vit avec ses deux chiens gâtés sous les auspices de sa reine de femme.

data.name: House Rules
entries: Comment tirer le meilleur parti des succès et des échecs critiques pour créer une aventure mémorable.

entries.name: Critical Care Unit
entries: Justin Peniston

entries.name: I was in trouble.
entries: Nous avions échappé de justesse aux petits humanoïdes noueux que nous connaissions sous le nom de Chimgani, mais un de leurs groupes de chasseurs nous avait rattrapés. Nous n'étions vêtus que de haillons, et la plupart de notre équipement était perdu ; je n'avais réussi qu'à prendre mon épée, mais je serais damné si je rentrais, ou descendais, sans me battre.

J'ai bondi pour attaquer un des chasseurs Chimgani, lui assénant un puissant coup, mais mon pied n'était pas ce qu'il aurait dû être. J'ai trébuché... et non seulement j'ai manqué mon adversaire, mais j'ai heurté un arbre. Ai-je mentionné que le coup était puissant ?
Mon épée était coincée dans l'arbre, et il faudrait de précieuses secondes pour la libérer, secondes que je n'avais pas.

Mais je savais me battre avec mes deux mains, et j'ai eu le temps de porter un dernier coup, mais seulement avec ma main libre en forme de poing. Désespérément, j'ai lancé un coup de poing... et je l'ai touché.
Hard.

Le chasseur Chimgani tournoya et tomba, et alors que j'essayais frénétiquement de libérer ma lame, je réalisai qu'il ne bougeait pas... ou ne respirait pas. J'ai souri et regardé autour de moi pour trouver quelqu'un d'autre à frapper.

C'était un vrai jeu auquel mes copains et moi jouions quand nous étions à l'université. C'était il y a assez longtemps pour que nous l'appelions encore "Avancé" (bien qu'il s'agisse de la 2e édition) pour le différencier des coffrets et des races qui étaient indiscernables des classes. (Oui, "{@race Elf}" était une classe, il fut un temps).

J'ai obtenu trois 20 d'affilée, puis un 18. Mon simple coup de poing était soudainement l'équivalent de quatre attaques réussies. J'ai fait tellement de dégâts non mortels, contre ce qui était essentiellement un orc, que je l'ai tué.

Mon personnage, Blackwood, était un {@class Ranger}, et était donc adepte de l'utilisation d'une arme de mêlée dans chaque main. J'ai gagné l'initiative ce round-là et j'ai attaqué avec mon épée bâtarde. J'ai obtenu un 1, un échec critique. Dans ce jeu particulier, cela signifiait que je perdais un tour, ce qui signifiait que je ne ferais effectivement aucun dégât ce tour-ci ou le suivant.

J'ai fait valoir que, puisque j'avais "{@optfeature Two-Weapon Fighting||two-weapon style}" comme l'une de mes caractéristiques de classe, je devrais quand même avoir une chance de donner un coup de poing, puisque mon MJ ne me laissait pas l'utiliser pour libérer l'épée. Il y a pensé une seconde et m'a laissé le faire... et cette fois, j'ai obtenu un 20.

Nous utilisions l'un des systèmes de coups critiques optionnels proposés dans 2E. En gros, si vous obteniez un 20, vous deviez "confirmer" votre coup critique par un autre jet d'attaque. Si vous touchiez à nouveau, vous aviez deux dégâts à appliquer. Si vous ratez le jet de confirmation, vous ne faites qu'un seul dégât. Mais si vous obtenez un 20 sur votre jet de confirmation, vous avez droit à un jet de confirmation supplémentaire... et ainsi de suite. Théoriquement, vous pouvez continuer à obtenir des 20 et à empiler des jets de dommages supplémentaires les uns sur les autres. Et c'est exactement ce que j'ai fait.

J'ai obtenu trois 20 d'affilée, puis un 18. Mon simple coup de poing était soudainement l'équivalent de quatre attaques réussies. J'ai fait tellement de dégâts non mortels, contre ce qui était essentiellement un {@creature orc}, que je l'ai tué. (Souvenez-vous de ceci si vous ne vous souvenez de rien d'autre, les enfants... parfois, les règles ne permettent pas de juger correctement ce qui devrait être un moment cool. C'est pourquoi le jugement du MJ l'emporte sur les règles).

Je ne peux pas dire à quel point ce moment était cool pour moi, et pour tout le monde à la table ce jour-là. C'était un combat de nettoyage, nous préparant pour le prochain chapitre de notre aventure. Mais mon groupe de joueurs a applaudi. Tout le monde était ravi et le combat n'était même pas terminé.

En ce qui me concerne, cela a changé la façon dont je voyais mon personnage. Lorsque j'ai créé mon personnage, faire du combat à mains nues l'un de ses traits n'était pas ce que je recherchais, mais maintenant cela correspond. Mon personnage était en quelque sorte l'anti-Aragorn ; il était de sang royal mais ses ancêtres étaient plus tyranniques que nobles, il était donc devenu un bandit. Faire de lui un bagarreur était la pièce manquante dont le concept du personnage avait besoin.

We played that campaign for a long time and that character was one of its defining elements. (Oh, and how I clowned my friends when they slipped up and called it the "Blackwood campaign," which happened more than once.) Now, I'm not saying that a kick-ass critical hit is going to be what makes a campaign great, but I believe that great adventures and great campaigns have signature moments, and that was one of them. It wouldn't have happened without that critical hit...
...or that critical miss.

Now we get around to how all of this is relevant three editions later, in the here and now. The critical hit system in Fight Edition is... let's call it uninspiring. (One of the rare times the game lets me down. As far as I'm concerned, it's the best version of the game to date.) IT's just a regular old double damage system: Double your damage dice, but not your modifiers, and you're done. It's not special, it's not something to look forwards two... but at least it's there. But the game has no critical miss system.

As far as critical misses, or critical fumbles as they were called then, 2nd Edition barely does anything with them, and 5E does nothing with them at all. I'm convinced they're as crucial, and fun, as a good critical hit system. Like critical hits, critical misses create moments.

In the above example, I never would have thrown the punch had I not rolled a 1 and gotten my sword stuck in the tree. The critical miss created an obstacle for me to overcome. It forced me to think about something besides swinging my sword, my go-to move. I'll grant you that opting for a thrown punch isn't exactly the work of a master tactician, but I was trying to make the rules work for me, and I did... and it changed our whole campaign.
...I'm not saying that a kick-ass critical hit is going to be what makes a campaign great, but I believe that great adventures and great campaigns have signature moments...
Now, we were using a different supplement for our critical misses. My GM had a copy of {@i The Best Dragon Magazine Vol. 4}, and one of the articles within was about critical misses.

This article had a focus on weapons being damages when a 1 was rolled, but it also included adding negative conditions like being disarmed, or even injuring oneself or a fellow party member. There were three tables, and two of those were extensive enough to require percentile tables rather than d20 or smaller, and there were time factors and yadda yadda yadda.

The beauty of 5E is how streamlined it is and doing research for this article really bears that out. I've loved almost every edition (except for the cursed 4th, of which we shall not speak), but looking back at the rules for 2nd Edition, the const of entry was just too high in terms of time investment. The older versions of the game were the bomb, but looking back on them now, they suffered from being excessively wordy, complicated, and humorless. The add-ons were pretty cool, though.

The game was complicated because it was complex and every new thing added a layer of customization that I dig to this day. But critical hits and misses don't need to be complex. Like the rest of combat, they should be simple and fun. I favor {@variantrule Alternative Criticals|RolledTold1|a simple set of rules}:

items.name: Only PCs and significant opponents should be capable of crits, whether you're taking hits or misses.
items.entry: No PC should be laid low because one of the Chimgani got a lucky shot. The woes of the Chimgani should come at the hands of the party, not the whims of the dice bag. That's just better storytelling.

items.name: Crits should have to be confirmed, and confirmations stack.
items.entry: Rolling a 20 or a 1 is already pretty badass, because a 20 always hits and a 1 always misses. Getting actual extra damage requires another successful attack roll, and every additional 20 or additional 1 earns you another set of damage to roll for (or an additional penalty). Does extra damage include bonuses like strength or magical bonuses, conventional wisdom says no... a critical hit doesn't mean you got stronger or that your sword got more magical. But you do you. Does a character get advantage or disadvantage on the confirmation roll? Again, I'd say no, but that sounds like a situational consideration to me. Note: where a confirmation roll for a critical hit is another successful attack roll, a critical miss should be confirmed by another failed attack roll!

items.name: Critical misses can take an abundance of forms.
items.entry: A critical hit is all about damage, because that's really all that anybody wants it to be about. Critical misses can and occasionally should result in damaging oneself or another party member, but that's not where I think the fun lies. I think the fun lies in negative conditions. It makes more sense to knock oneself {@condition prone} (or {@condition unconscious}!) than simply to do damage to oneself. Or maybe the encounter has a goal, and the critical miss moves the party a step back from that goal. As far as stacking goes, you can worsen the condition, say from {@condition incapacitated} to {@condition unconscious}, or you can add to the duration of the condition, say from one round to {@dice d4} rounds.

entries: Honestly, that's as complicated as I think this needs to be. I'll put a wee chart at the end of this article, so you can randomly generate appropriate negative conditions. It won't be exhaustive; you can sub out conditions as you see fit. (Is the parting fighting a tentacle monster? Sub in the {@condition grappled} condition! Are they fighting a medusa? A character might stumble into her line of sight, so add the {@condition petrified} condition!)

Customize this as you see fit; make it work situationally. Maybe if your players fail their confirmation roll, you decide they automatically do max damage. Maybe confirming a critical hit activates a power, or restores the use of a power. Maybe a critical miss causes their disguises to fail, rather than having any sort of combat effect. Do what works for you.

This is not a crit system that is likely to grow out of control. No body locations, no crazy charts or rolls, no real work on the GM's part. Lest you worry about PCs stomping around ripping off mega-stacks of crits, I should say that in the entire duration of that 5+ year campaign, it only happened twice... and I was the guy that rolled them both times. (Maybe someday I'll tell you guys about the {@monster cave fisher|VGM}!) The odds of rolling two 20s in a row are 1 in 400. Hitting three in a row was a 1 in 8000 shot.
But if you're the sort that likes extra charts, here's the one I promised you, a list of appropriate conditions for simple combat. Feel free to add or substitute conditions as you see fit.
{@table Critical Misses|RolledTold1|Critical Misses Table}
My goal with this article is to give you an example of how to make your own game more fun. Use this, modify it, even ignore it, as long as you're enjoying the game!

entries.name: Bring On the Booty!
entries: E.L. Thomas

If you are a fan of randomly generating treasure for your games or, on occasion, get stuck without having fully prepared the loot for your game, then random treasure tables are your best friend. Being random, the treasure tables don't always give you treasure that fits the tone or theme of your adventure. So, if you have a "pirate" theme going on or just want to get your Long John Silvers on, here are some miscellaneous pieces of treasure for you.

entries.name: For Individual Treasure
entries: When you randomly generate pp, or platinum pieces, on an individual treasure roll, you can substitute half the value for a roll on the {@table Weird Stuff Art Object/Magic Trinket Table|RolledTold1} below instead or just pick one that catches your fancy. When using this table, add the Challenge Rating to the rolled result. Example: you roll an 8 on your 1d20 for a Challenge 4 creature so you would use the 12 result.

entries.name: For Art Object Rolls for Treasure Hoards
entries: When you roll a result of art object for your randomly generated treasure hoards, substitute an item of appropriate value from the Seafarers' and Buccaneers' Art Object Tables.

data.name: Adventure Craft
entries: Tips and tricks for working obligatory thug attacks into every game session.

entries.name: Obligatory Thug Attacks
entries: E.L. Thomas
Now I know the phrase "obligatory thug attack" does not sound all that thrilling. Well, in a roleplay session it is, and it can be so much more.
An obligatory thug attack is any combat, threat of combat, or skilled challenge encounter that is not super difficult or dangerous for the PCs (though they don't know that).

Such an encounter has tons of uses for a game master: It is an easy way to get an adventure started and a good way to liven up a slow session, without going too far off the storyline. They make a fine way to have reoccurring foes or enemies show up every few games to remind the player they still have unfinished business and a spectacular way to garner the attentions of distracted players. They are nice when an impromptu combat comes from some roleplaying. Best of all, they let the PCs show off and kick ass!

I always try to work at least one obligatory thug attack into every game session. Sometimes, my players do it for me and that is even better. As a GM, you have a lot to keep track of: rules, initiative order, spell durations, conditions, monster hit points, and all manner of stuff that makes the game keep rolling along. Because of all a GM has to do during a game session, sometimes you miss that the game is lagging, your players' attentions are wandering from the game, or it is just downright boring. That is when your players will usually go a bit rogue and stir things up and trigger an obligatory thug attack encounter.

While running from the hip and coming up with player-generated combat can be difficult, it does make your game feel like more of a living world and less of a railroad. So, let your players have these moments.
A few good examples of player-triggered obligatory thug attacks are:

items: When one or more of the players try to intimidate or deceive their way out of/into trouble
When they pick a fight or try to "borrow"/steal something
When players go looking for impromptu sport (gambling, arm wrestling, drinking contests, archery contests, and the like

entries: Such encounters are always fun, but most times must be run from the hip. It's a skill that is learned over time, though I'm sure there are those that can do it with ease the first time around. While running from the hip and coming up with player-generated combat can be difficult, it does make your game feel like more of a living world and less of a railroad. So, let your players have these moments.
While player-triggered ones can work themselves out (one way or another), I want to give you a few tricks and tips for purposely working obligatory thug attacks into every game session.

entries.name: Foe Foreshadowing
entries: This is used to clue in or give a hint to your players as to what they might be up against. It could also give them a few clues as to what kind of threats are in the wilderness they are entering. It could even be a small scouting or hunting party of humanoids or giants, or a single {@creature worg} that is just an outlier for a whole pack.

Foe Foreshadowing is also a good way to warn your players when they might be getting ready to enter an area or undertake a combat that is far beyond their abilities to handle or survive. That way, you don't have to give the old "You guys might want to rethink this" line. Just give them a taste of what's to come and let them make the decisions. Just because players are 2nd level, doesn't mean that every path they choose has a balanced encounter awaiting them to best. {@creature ogre||Ogres}, giants, {@creature orc} tribes, and dragons have to live somewhere. In a living world, it sometimes behooves characters to run, instead of fight. This way, you can slaughter them with a clear conscience and a "What did you think the ogre meant by 'Me mates is gonna eat ya fer dis,' that he bleated before he died?" or a "Nobody forced you guys to charge into a cave you knew had ogres in it without scouting it out first. I mean the ogre you guys killed that was dragging the dead goat was headed someplace."

entries.name: Inadequate Ambush
entries: This one feels dangerous to your players. An ambush will put them on their heels, but a push-over ambush keeps you from killing them in the process. It also lets the players think that the bad guys have either badly underestimated them, or it makes them feel totally tough when they turn the tables on the ambushers. It can be combined with Foe Foreshadowing or The Clue-by-Four to do double-duty tactical excitement and helpful info.

entries.name: Paper Tigers
entries: Time to make the PCs think they are in over their heads, with three or four times the number of foes they thought should be in the battle, because there are! Start with two full-stat foes you want to use, say {@creature gnoll||gnolls}—now we need a massive pack of these critters; that is where minions come in (use the {@creature gnoll} stat block but lower their AC by 2 and make them have only 1 hit point). Now you have 2 normal gnolls and 20 paper tiger or minion gnolls. When us a battle kicks off, your players will be more than worried when they are facing what looks like 22 gnolls! Facing down hordes of foes (even 1 hp foes) makes for epic battles, and even more so than an Inadequate Ambush. It makes all the players feel like heroes. It is a bit more dangerous, but way too cool not to use every couple of games.

entries.name: The Clue-by-Four
entries: This is kind of like Foe Foreshadowing, but more to get your players thinking or fighting in the right direction to push the story along.

Say you are running a game that involves taking on a cult—but the players have missed some important clue that would lead them to uncover that all the disappearances in own are due to the cult taking them, and the players all look bored, annoyed, or befuddled. Ambush them with some cultist. Not only will it get the table rolling, but the story will have advanced. Now they discover clues you insert: what the cult is all about. Perhaps an NPC they met earlier is one of the now dead cultists at the PCs' feet. Maybe the Clue-By-Four lets them know they are up against a cult. It lets them know where to start looking for the missing folk or at least pushes them onto the cult's trail in some way. That is hitting your players over the heads with a Clue-by-Four without having to blatantly tell them. This way they think they figured something out and you don't have to break the fort wall to tell them and railroad them as to what to do.

entries.name: The Warm-Up
entries: The warm-up is a very good way to get the game started with some action.
{@note Editor's Note: See {@book Running the Game|RolledTold3}—{@link Instant Action|https://www.rolledandtold.com/2018/11/28/running-the-game-instant-action/} in our November Issue!—Steenz}

It gets all the players fully engaged, and, if they are not careful, takes a few resources—spell slots, magic item charges, potions, limited use feats, and abilities. I also like to use a warm-up attack right before the PCs face off with a big bad. Sure, it is cool to take out a pile of folks with a well-timed {@spell fireball}, but the party will be missing that 3rd-level spell slot when the {@creature lich} hurls their own {@spell fireball} an it is cast with a 9th-level spell slot. Sure could have used an extra {@spell counterspell} to stop that 20-ft. radius, {@damage 14d6} of fiery death coming at the party. So this is not only fun, but a way to teach your players resource conservation.

entries.name: There Will Be Blood
entries: It's just what it says. Maybe the game session you planned is going to be or was heavy on roleplaying? Well, as a good GM you need to try and include everyone. The {@race half-orc} {@class barbarian} with the Charisma of 6 is not going to have much to do when the game is about negotiations. Sure, they can stand around and look menacing and be ready if things go bad, but if they don't you now have a player who came to your table and got to do little or nothing. I can tell you, that is far from cool. No matter how engaging you think your game or story is, a little combat is kind of a necessity in tabletop gaming. To that thought, this is where There Will Be Blood comes in. Start, slip in, or end a session with a short and easy combat. It doesn't take a pile of planning on your part, and it keeps everybody happy.

Try them, you and your players will like them. These thug attacks give you an excuse to throw some "Are you not entertained?" {@i Gladiator}-style lines at your players. That, my fellow cheesy game masters, is GM gold!

data.name: Memorable Monsters
entries: Tactics for befriending monsters and other things you encounter on your adventure.

entries.name: Befriending the Monster (in You)
entries: Jen Vaughn

entries.name: Maybe you've never moved cities or states, let alone schools. Consider playing role-playing games as adventuring into a new school with a new set of problems: where to sit at lunch, what after-school activity to sign up for, and whom to sit next to on the bus.
entries: If you were approaching role-playing like a new school, you wouldn't immediately pull out your sharp ruler and slash someone's calves, would you? You would try to find a common subject, or in the case, a similar language to speak. Friends or allies can offer you even more than rummaging through the pockets of a swiftly-cooling corpse.

What do friends offer you? They know where the good food is, have great stone collections, and know the good local bands. In tabletop games, they could be NPCs who join the group for a while, guide you to a lucrative side-quest, or help reunite a member of the group with a missing friend. There is no limit to what a friend can do for you, on and off table.

And to be fair, there is a tactical reason to befriend aggressors and adventurers on your own quests: bodies add up. People are going to start looking for you. The easiest way to find an adventuring party is to follow the line of rotting corpses left in their wake. And that doesn't seem very smart, does it?

entries.name: Tactics for Befriending Monsters and Other Things You Encounter
entries: (Also a heads-up for GMs who might not be expecting this. Monsters do not need to dwell in just dungeons, they can be around corners of cities, in the library, at the tavern. Humans aren't the only ones who reside in cities within the realms.)

entries.name: Disarm with Charm
entries: Immediately compliment the approaching party. Is one goblin coming out of the forest wearing a bandana for a local sports team? Is that the most pearl-encrusted sword handle you have ever seen? Make up something or ask the GM to describe something—they'll play along!

entries.name: Ask for Directions
entries: You don't need to pull out your map—we're not comparing compass roses, nor do we need directions to the dungeon or tower where you are heading. Ask the giants for the best off-the-beaten-path tavern for nibbles, vittles, and libations. These other adventurers and monsters don't have to be antagonistic—they could even know of the best fantasy pizza in the realms from working there as a youngling (they still have the oven burn marks on their arms to prove it!).

entries.name: Be the Information Desk
entries: You've been walking through this forest or beach for HOURS. Did you just encounter the angriest set of flying snakes behind you? And barely escaped with your lives? Let the lovely owlbears in your life know what's coming up on their path; maybe you'll be rewarded for your thoughtfulness.

entries.name: Challenge them to a Dance-Off
entries: If it's obvious there MUST be a fight of some kind, try turning it into something less contact-heavy by challenging those pesky kobolds to a dance-off, push-up contest, or seeing who can sing high enough to shatter this crystal goblet your thief stole from the last tavern. What do the friends you're playing with like? Think about that and how you can incorporate it into the fantasy realm.

entries.name: Ask for the Manager
entries: Okay, dear reader, I'm suggesting this almost jokingly but...MAYBE management doesn't know their employed striges are looting on the side and harassing you in the forest OR this forest is full of unpaid interns who need someone to help them mobilize against management. You could be the catalyst for change for them.
The easiest way to find an adventuring party is to follow the line of rotting corpses left in their wake. And that doesn't seem very smart, does it?

These tips might also be useful to incorporate into gameplay, as sometimes a long, drawn out combat can become less and less fun. Could your in-game rendition of a pop song stop everyone from fighting? You won't know until you try.

What does "monster" mean anyway? Something you don't understand and can't comprehend. And you can't learn more if you kill before investigating and asking questions. A monster is a friend you haven't met yet. Most monsters have unique society standards that can echo in your encounters—a gatherer goblin wouldn't hurt a fly (or you) compared to the hunter goblins.

Should you and your adventuring party dispense with fighting, remember enemies offer you nothing but anger and the short path to dull weapons. I'm not suggesting you let your character die from kindness when you are up against a gnoll who will not speak to you and is continuously slashing at you. But given good rolls, you can knock others out instead of taking them out. Maybe they're under a spell you haven't detected or are acting out of fear for a kidnapped family member. You can always loot their passed-out body to learn more information (and snag a library card for whatever town they're from—it's HIGHLY useful).
Or once you have an enemy tied up, you are FREE to question them about the best tavern pizza pies on the Sword Coast.

entries.name: Monster Mediation
entries: Maybe your adventuring party is at the right place, right time to see one set of monsters attacking a different species. It's time to don the helm of mediation (made that one up!) and problem-solve.

entries.name: 1) Separate the Groups
entries: You need to get them to stop fighting first or to cool everyone down if they are about to draw weapons. This is best done with the aforementioned tactics, namely jokes to dissolve some of the tension.
In our example, a {@creature minotaur} keeps stealing pies from a {@creature kobold}, who puts them outside their cave to cool.

entries.name: 2) Listen to Each Side
entries: Get each group/person to state why they are upset, from beginning to end if possible. It doesn't matter who goes first but one monster/person at a time.
Do not let the kobold or minotaur argue or speak over each other.

entries.name: 3) Restate the Case and the Positives
entries: Sometimes hearing a problem in a third party's words (someone who has little or nothing to gain from choosing a side) will turn a light on for one of the sides. It's usually not that easy but it's fun to dream. Focusing also on any positives is helpful.
Hey, at least the kobold is making GOOD pies, right? The minotaur wouldn't eat a garbage pie.

entries.name: 4) Find the Middle
entries: In most conflicts, there is a way to compromise. To meet in the middle so everyone leaves smiling, or at least not bleeding, broken, and dead. Does a flying monster keep stealing pies from a local baker? What are some possible solutions? Go ahead and write down three; we can look at them later.*

entries.name: 5) Focus on the Future
entries: This might be the hardest step, but what can the parties involved do differently in the future? Assigning blame won't necessarily encourage change on the guilty party.
Ready?

entries.name: *Okay, it's later. Some options I came up with (maybe yours are similar!):
items: Make the minotaur pay for the pies. This is not a great example, despite being simple and logical, because it doesn't focus on the future. The minotaur might have been raised in an area where things not guarded are up for grabs.
Have the minotaur supply items to be baked into pies. They can provide items that maybe a kobold would have never seen before!
Get the kobold and minotaur to go deeper into business together. Turn the minotaur not into a supplier but a partner via a pie delivery service! Now the kobold is making pies for money too!

entries: To encourage creativity and thinking outside the box, or in this case outside the dungeon: think monstrous. I'm a big proponent of not playing as a human in role-playing games. We wear so many masks and faces throughout our every day—this is FANTASY. Let's start with maybe some big lower teeth poking out of our mouth, a set of horns, or glowing eyes. People might treat you differently, you may have to eat food differently, but this will help you adapt to new circumstances (in and out of game).

Let's be frank—as far as we know, most RPG manuals were written from the point of views of humans, ergo the default point of view IS human. Even if the lands are equally split between {@race human||humans}, {@race elf||elves}, {@race orc|ERLW|orcs}, {@race goblin|VGM|goblins}, {@race tiefling||tieflings}, etc., your GM will mostly likely operate under the idea of humans as default. Also, playing as a quote-unquote monster and putting yourself into their shoes (or horns) will give you insight to use when befriending the same species in the future.

Which is why it's so enriching and narratively fun to play as something else in the manual. I'm partial to demonic monsters like {@race tiefling||tieflings} (basically like {@creature gargoyle||gargoyles}, born from evil magicks). Sometimes I add a twist playing them as if they've escaped the limiting confines and expectations of their species. The play of nature vs nurture is a narrative thread you can all use! Think of if in the "real world" a friend grew up in a meat-eating household but wants to learn more about plant-based diets and experiment with making meals without meat. They are getting to play with their food (har har) and you can do the same at your tabletop game.

For example: Playing as a {@race lizardfolk|VGM} or {@race dragonborn}, you aren't biologically seeking the same types of things as warm-blooded creatures. You can even play into the ectothermic nature. Ectotherms cannot derive their own body heat and must absorb it from the sun or warm things like fire. During a short rest, you have to sunbathe to keep up your energy. Smack on some personality like dressing and acting in goth fashion (and hating the sun) while being a lizard-person and you have a lot of internal conflict to play with.

A smooth-talking {@race elf} will get much further naturally in a conversation with politicians than a ham-and-cheese-fisted {@race orc|ERLW}, unless you pump up the charisma points when you level up. If we made a chart of playable monsters and characters in the game, we'd see all the same personality traits in humans are also in the monsters and vice versa. It is the extremes that traits are pushed to that are the base for said monsters. Or as I like to call them, friends.

entries.name: Jen Vaughn
entries: dual-classes as both a writer ({@i Goosebumps: Download and Die}) and an artist ({@i Teenage Wasteland}, many issues of {@i Rolled & Told}). When not playing 5th edition, Jen is RECORDING playing D&D with her all-ages podcast, {@i d20 Dames} (as a {@race tiefling}, of course).

data.name: Running the Game
entries: Build a new level of depth to your game with these four foundational pillars.

entries.name: How to Craft the Perfect Game
entries: Teo Acosta

A prayer to the old gods is whispered into a fist clutching a plastic icosahedron. The d20 bounces across the table covered in cups, snacks, miniatures, and notepaper. Six sets of eyes watch with bated breath. The die slowly topples onto its result: 19. A hit! Someone is cheering but you can't hear it over your own hurrah. The table shakes as the players rejoice and your face hurts from smiling. The adventure is over.

A d20 rolls across the table, half-thrown half-dropped. It bounces into a painted miniature and reveals a 10. A hit. The monster is defeated. The players have won. There is a pause, and someone says, "Wait, what were we doing here again?" The adventure is over.
Which of these tables will remember this night?
Which of these tables would you want to sit at?

I've spent a large portion of my life researching and crafting adventures. I've GMed hundreds of games over the years and have experienced both tables first hand. I've learned how to avoid bad GM habits and how to turn low-focus games into awesome adventures.

I believe there are four pillars of a good campaign. Plot, Thrill, Intrigue, and Satisfaction. WHAT? That doesn't make sense! What about about monsters? What about role play? WHAT ABOUT COMBAT!?! While these aspects are all part of the experience, I don't believe they are all the foundational pillars of a great adventure.

If given the opportunity, share a pint of ale (ginger ale for the youngins) with a white witch or greybeard. Ask them about their most memorable gaming war stories. I guarantee you the moment that have stayed with them were not the 5th turn of combat versus a {@creature red dragon}. It was most likely the sense of dread in the moment the rogue rolled a 2 on a search for traps, or the thrill of convincing a town that it was, in fact, infested with {@creature vampire||vampires} and not spooky-bitey-priests.

As a younger GM, I would learn about a new feature or some kind of puzzle and dream of someone presenting this encounter to me. My focus was building impossible amazing traps, insane encounters, bizarre puzzles and designing endless war campaigns. I would spend dozens of hours on every adventure creating the tiniest details to guide the players to slowly unravel the main arcs of the campaign. It was a perfect campaign.
It was a "perfect" campaign... for me.

Unfortunately, my players had different interest. The party would forget NPC names, lose track of goals, get hyper-focused on the wrong details, get stuck on riddles, or worse, one player would solve everything while the rest of the party floated by. I had crafted a water park for the players, but they didn't want to wait in line for the rides. I was focused on the events instead of how to get my players invested.

The easiest way to get your players invested is to build the campaign around them. A topic that is rarely discussed is the tone of an adventure. Some people want dark brooding grimdark adventures where everyone's a backstabbing villain; other people want a little dark but overall uplifting experience. Before starting your campaign it's wise to discuss the tone of the game with your party. It also helps to look at their lives outside of the campaign.

Sometimes people don't know that they need a fun, easy-peasy adventure. Don't set up a brutal moral-questioning adventure if some of your players are having a hard time with something in their everyday lives. Know the crowd.
How do you get players invested in the game? Here are some questions you can ask yourself while designing an adventure:

items.name: PLOT:
items.entry: How do you hook your players into an engaging adventure?

items.name: THRILL:
items.entry: How do you make each adventure a thrilling experience?

items.name: INTRIGUE:
items.entry: How do we make the players excited for future adventures?

items.name: SATISFACTION:
items.entry: How do we make sure the players are fulfilled?

entries: Let's start at the top.

entries.name: Plot
entries: How do you hook your players into an engaging adventure? "What are your players' motivations?" "Why do they care?" There is sort of an unspoken rule of collaborative gaming to be like: "Whatever the adventure is, we'll do it because otherwise what are we doing today?"
BUT it is always better to have your player's characters have something invested in the adventure itself.

There is no small answer to this. Try building a fun NPC to help give your players something to care about. A lovable underdog will usually help garner the empathy of the group. Once you have that, use it to its fullest. MAKE THEM FEEL!

My most successful NPC came by accident. In an adventure the players were attacked by a group of {@creature goblin||goblins}, combat was nearly over, and one goblin was left. I had written some backstory for this area and wanted to add some spice to the mix, so I had him throw down his weapon and say how sorry he was. His tribe had been coerced into attacking travelers by a beast called The Wolf. The real hook was his persona. His name was "Stomp" and he spoke in a small, apologetic voice.

What I didn't expect was the group to basically adopt him. They fed him, brushed his hair and had him lead them to his tribe where they liberated them from "The Wolf" (a level 7 {@race orc|VGM} {@class fighter}/jerk). They have Stomp a bunch of gold and a smooch on the forehead goodbye. The players often asked NPCs if they had heard any news from the goblin plains, specifically asking about Stomp, and often sent portions of their loot and supplies to his tribe.
Stomp gave the players something to care about in this world.

entries.name: Thrill
entries: How do you make each adventure a thrilling experience?

This is probably the most well-known pillar of table top gaming. What makes a thrilling game is a source of debate and friendly contention. I think it's important to acknowledge that sometimes the most thrilling experience is NOT combat. Sometimes it's coercing information out of a diplomat, flirting your way past a bouncer, or out-drinking a dwarven war party. Are you having trouble making your adventure thrilling? Here are some ideas that will help get started.

Paint your group's party as false villains. did they save a town from burning OR did they start the fire and extort the village to put out the fire in exchange for gold?! another version of this is build a "rival" group of adventurers who your party gets mistaken for. How do they prove they AREN'T a group of {@creature bandit||bandits}? Make sure to design a plot point to eventually clear their name... unless they go evil.

Make the party risk something important to them. Gold might excite an NPC but to a player gold, silver, and copper coins are just a number on their character sheet! When your players started making their characters, what where their characters' goals? Do they have a deed to their family's farm? Does a character have a dark or mysterious past? At character creation encourage your players to give their characters a secret they wouldn't like the rest of the party to know!

Some people want dark brooding grimdark adventures where everyone's a backstabbing villain; other people want a little dark but overall uplifting experience. Before starting your campaign it's wise to discuss the tone of the game with your party.

If you are intent on focusing on combat let me suggest one fun little trick! In one particularly action-based session the players had about 10 minutes to make it through a series of encounters. To make it more exciting, I put an actual timer on the table. The players had 10 real minutes to do what they had to do. I had never seen my players make decisions so quickly! While this is a fun mechanism, don't do it often. It may be too stressful for some people. I know several people who really appreciate how much time they can think about their new move.

entries.name: Intrigue
entries: How do we make players excited for future adventures?

Recurring villains! Ancient prophecies! Looming disaster! Exposition! What will make your players stoked to come back to the table? What will they think about when they're on break from work? This doesn't need to be a literal villain. Sometimes a concept can be strong enough to keep your players curious. I consume a lot of media and often take notes of how much a film or book will hint at something before showing it. Have an upcoming spooky ice dungeon? Throw in some chilly dialog in your NPCs. Be subtle, but emphatic with your hints!

Another method is to expand your focus on world building. Do the players travel to the same place frequently? Have their favorite NPCs grow over time. Magnar the Beautiful has opened his first barbershop! Stomp the Goblin has set up a trade route between his tribe and the town. The guard who runs the gate had a kid and named it after one of your players. Spend a little time on it, make a chart showing your progress. These kinds of moments give your world depth, which will have your players starting to ask questions like "What else is happening in this world?" which will excite them to explore and investigate your game every session!

entries.name: Satisfaction
entries: How do we make sure the players have a good time?

In the game, make sure to reward your players. Cool moments are just as valuable as new weapons. Never steal a moment from them. If you have some dramatic twist in your adventure, think about how it would feel to the players. A slippery villain is VERY different from a stolen victory. Designing a hard adventure is very different than designing a mean one.

A great way to ensure your players are satisfied is to set up goals for them to accomplish. When designing your adventures make sure you build easy- and hard-to-achieve goals. Set up the situation so they save the prince, but the kidnapper has escaped. You can only do this so many times before the players will assume they can't catch the kidnapper. An alternative route is to catch the kidnapper and find out they were hired! BUT BY WHOM?! That's up to you. NPC friendly backstabs can be fun, but don't break your player's trust.

Out of game, you can usually tell how much fun a group has had at the end of a long day of gaming. Everyone's a little different in how they display their enjoyment. Don't fret if players don't throw confetti at you at the end of every adventure! I make a habit of doing a very casual small-post mortem. Encourage constructive criticism! "Did you have fun? What was your favorite moment?" If they had a bad time don't take it in a negative light. Failure is knowledge! Listen and learn from your mistakes. GMing is hard work!

5E is a conversation. You need to listen just as much as you talk. What do your players want? Are they having fun? What does their body language say? Know your players. Never be afraid to try new things. Go to the dollar store (or Halloween store if you're lucky) and pick up some fun props. Handing a fake ring in the real world when a player finds a cursed ring can be so fun! Trial and error is a great way to learn what your players like. Talk after an adventure. Most importantly, don't forget this is a game. Make sure everyone is having fun, including yourself.
Plot, Thrill, Intrigue, and Satisfaction! When you're building your adventure refer to these four pillars and I guarantee you will build a new level of depth to your game.

data.name: House Rules
entries: Throw the rule book out the window and learn to use spawn mechanics in your adventures.

entries.name: Spawn Mechanics
entries: E.L. Thomas

Now if you are new to playing the 5th edition of the world's most popular RPG, then this little tidbit of game mastery nonsense may not be for you. Though it should be! If you are a "by the book" kind of gamer, then this may not sound like anything you want in your game. Though you and your players are missing out. Now I can go on and on and tell every one of you that "this may not be for you, but it really is"... but I won't. Because if you don't use a bit of this rules-breaking mechanic in one of your play sessions, your game will be lesser for it. You need SPAWN MECHANICS in your life!

I will not pretend to have invented spawn mechanics. That was done way back in 1985 by Atari Games when they brough us Gauntlet, in all its massive standing cabinet, hack-and-slashing, "Red Warrior needs food badly!", "Green Elf is about to die!" 8-bit glory. For crusty old gamers like myself who have been rolling funky shaped dice and scratching crazy Gygaxian dungeons on graph paper since I was ten in 1981, Gauntlet showed me (to my players' chagrin and joy) that tides of enemies rolling towards you cannot only be cool, heroic, and fear inducing, but a needed component of my game.

If you need examples from folks far better than myself, you need to look no further than some of the movies that are so beloved by fans of our shared geeky ilk. The best example I can think of is Peter Jackson's version of Lord of the Rings. In Fellowship alone, Jackson gives us awesome examples of spawning monsters. He gives a tide of goblins along with their pet cave troll in the Mines of Moria scenes. We see our beloved heroes—backs to the wall, weapons at the ready—and a cave troll comes crashing into the tomb, a tide of rabid goblins in tow! If that doesn't blow your hair back, how about a mass horde of Uruk-hai orcs flooding through the hilly forest bellowing "Find the Halfling!" The battles are in-your-face furious, wild and glorious action. You can get the same effects at your game table with spawn mechanics.

To be up front and fully truthful, using spawn mechanics is not only disregarding every rule on building encounters in the rulebooks, but more so shooting them dead. This will make every rules-lawyer cringe and clutch their oh-so-manipulated core rulebooks to their chest and accuse you of blasphemy! Let them. Because sometimes you have to think (or in this case play) out of the box. Being a Game Master isn't always easy. Nor is the task of keeping your players engaged, entertained, and ready to come back next session for more. We sacred few who take up our screens and produce game after game of goodness for our players need all the help we can get. We need a bag of tricks to keep things from getting boring. Spawn mechanics are just one of the many crazy tricks I have collected over my nearly forty years of dungeon crafting and shoved into my bag of holding.
Let's lay out the basics of using spawn mechanics. I like to break it down into five simple categories: Trigger, Emanation, Generation, Duration, and Reward/Result.

entries.name: Trigger
entries: What causes the spawn. It could be something the PCs touch (a magically alarmed door or object), a roll the PCs failed (like say a failed {@skill Stealth} check), the area they are in (like breaking into or out of prison), or just being in the wrong place and time (interrupting a dark ritual in a cult's inner sanctum, or kicking in the wrong door and finding not a couple of {@creature bugbear||bugbears} on the other side, but thirty).

entries.name: Emanation
entries: Where on the map or play area the spawning encounters start from as they enter the encounter.

entries.name: Generation
entries: How they spawn and how many are spawned at one time. Are they sent from another section of the adventure, spewed forth from a magical portal, or maybe just summoned or created by some infernal monster generator—like in our beloved Gauntlet? However or wherever they spawn from, it needs to be explained and we need to have a set way to determine how many show up at one time.

entries.name: Duration
entries: How long they keep spawning. Is it until a set number shows up, random dice rolls, or something that can be stopped in game—such as shutting down a magic portal? Or maybe it's until the PCs exit the area.

entries.name: Reward/Result
entries: What your players get for putting up with, thwarting, or merely surviving your spawn encounter. It could be simple XP or some other story element, goal, or loot, figuring XP is just a general guideline more than a hard and fast rule. Take the base XP of the monster you are planning to spawn and multiply it by 4 as base XP for your Spawner (x2 if you reduce or limit the monsters in some way, or if there's an advantageous reward from the PCs). Add 10% of the base XP (or +10 or +20 XP in our Spawner examples) bonus for each round the spawner is active, dependent on how nasty the monsters or situation is.
With these five factors in mind, let's throw together a few Encounter examples of spawning mechanics that you can just plug right into your game.

Firstly, how about one I like to call the Dinner Bell or Alarm Spawner. I use this kind of monster spawn if the PCs alert the bad guys to their presence—like if they are trying to sneak into or out of an area rife with threats. Or if they just kick in the door with a devil may care attitude without fully scouting out the battle beforehand. This one simulates all the bad guys converging and/or giving chase to the PCs.

entries.name: Trigger: Failed Stealth Check
entries: The PCs are spotted while trying to sneak through a massive goblin underground stronghold.

entries.name: Emanation: Random
entries: {@creature goblin||Goblins} come dashing in from every entrance and exit to the area the PCs are currently in.

entries.name: Generation: Initiative Generation
entries: Every round for the duration on Initiative 20 (losing ties), {@dice 1d4 + 1} {@creature goblin||Goblins} come running into the battle, trying to hurriedly ready their weapons and armor for battle. Give the goblins disadvantage on attack rolls and -2 AC, as they were ill-prepared having been in their own living space and not on guard for intruders. Also reduce the base goblin HP 7 to only HP 1 each.

entries.name: Duration: Area
entries: The goblins keep coming until the PCs exit the area at the end of a round that no goblins are alive or conscious and find a place to get out of sight and begin to {@skill Stealth} once more.

entries.name: Reward/Result: XP/Discord for 1 Hour
entries: Base XP of 100 + 10 combat round after the first encounter lasts, since the PCs screwed up and failed the {@skill Stealth} checks and got spotted. / Discord grants the PCs advantage on {@skill Stealth} checks as long as they move cautiously through the goblin territory, because the goblins are unnerved and searching in hurried panic for more threats.

As you can see in our first example, you may need to tone down any bad guys you spawn. The goal is not to slaughter your PCs, but to add tension, a sense of urgency, or wild and furious action. You want to make the encounter memorable and give your players some gaming goodness that will be remembered and retold. Most likely, your players won't remember the time they killed six goblins in a cave. Though you can bet they will remember the time the clumsy {@class fighter} tripped over a skull and banged his shield like a gong and alerted every goblin within earshot. Then they had to hack their way clear as thirty goblins came rushing at them until they could get to a place to try and avoid the rest of the goblin town coming down on their heads.
Here are a few other simple spawners you can look at before you make your own.

entries.name: Trigger: Encounter Goal
entries: The abyssal portal is part of the encounter and is already triggered when the encounter begins, and closing it is the purpose for the encounter.

entries.name: Emanation: Static
entries: The {@creature dretch} that are spawned do so within {@dice 1d4} squares of the portal.

entries.name: Generation: Initiative Generation
entries: Every round until the portal is sealed on Initiative 20 (losing ties), 2 {@creature dretch} spawn from the portal location.

entries.name: Duration: Task Ending
entries: The dretch keep spawning until the portal is sealed by succeeding on (4) consecutive Intelligence ({@skill Arcana}) {@dc 15} checks. If one is failed, you must begin anew from the beginning. Additionally, if any dretch are within 30 feet of the portal, any {@skill Arcana} check made to close it is done so at disadvantage.

entries.name: Reward/Result: XP/Ending the Threat Upon Closure
entries: XP 200 + 20 per combat round the encounter lasts. / When the last of the four consecutive {@skill Arcana} checks is completed, all dretch are immediately sucked back into the portal an instant before it slams shut.

entries.name: The Rolling Tide of Hungry Rats Spawner
Trigger: Area Lair
entries: While crawling through a dungeon or sewer, the PCs happen to stumble into the nesting area of thousands of rats, and they are hungry. The rats swarm towards the PCs in a tide.

entries.name: Emanation: Directional
entries: The {@creature swarm of rats} (enough to fill one end of the area and any area that they pass through), constantly fills in behind as they roll towards in tide of gnashing teeth.

entries.name: Generation: Endless Threat
entries: The number of {@creature swarm of rats||rat swarms} is innumerable. The tide of vermin flows over every PC as they try to flee. Each PC suffers AUTOMATIC damage each round on any hit to roll result besides a natural 1, though only suffers automatic damage if being attacked by a single swarms of rats (7 piercing damage, or 14 if they don't take at least one Move each turn). Any attacks made against the tide of rats have advantage because of the massive size of the threat.
Being a Game Master isn't always easy. Nor is the task of keeping your players engaged, entertained, and ready to come back next session for more.

entries.name: Duration: Until Stopped
entries: The tide of rat swarms harries the PCs until it is stopped using a massive amount of oil or acid, or by area effect spells and attacks that cause enough damage to slay 10 swarm of rats' worth of hit points (240 HP) in a single combat round, or they just keep coming.

entries.name: Reward/Result: XP/Survival
entries: XP 200 + 10 each combat round after the first. / They get to live and tell the tale.

entries.name: Trigger: Foe Activated
entries: Either a vile {@creature necromancer|VGM} or his minions take an Action to activate the skeleton machine when the Encounter begins by pulling a series of levers.

entries.name: Emanation: Area Touching
entries: All spawned {@creature skeleton||skeletons} start in any square touching the machine.

entries.name: Generation: Activated random
entries: {@dice 2d4} skeletons spawn from the skeleton machine each round on the same initiative until it is deactivated or destroyed. This number can be reduced (see Duration for details).

entries.name: Duration: Until Deactivated or Destroyed
entries: Deactivating the skeleton machine requires (4) Actions in succession on (4) Dexterity ({@item Thieves' Tools|PHB}) {@dc 20} to deactivate; each success counts as 10 Hit Points of damage. Characters trained in {@skill Arcana} gain Advantage on these checks. Or, the {@object skeleton machine|RolledTold4} can be destroyed by dealing it damage. For every 10 hit points of damage dealt to it, the skeleton machine spawns -1 less skeletons until reduced to 0 hit points. Example: when it takes 10 hp of damage it spawns {@dice 2d4 -1}, after 20 hp it spawns {@dice 2d4 -2}, after 30 hp {@dice 2d4 -3}, and at 40 hp it is destroyed.

entries.name: Reward/Result: XP/—
entries: XP 200 + 10 each combat round after the first. /—
